Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a High Performance Computer to Integrate Data Intensive Research and Education: Bringing HPC to South Jersey

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal seeks support for the acquisition of a shared high-performance computing (HPC) cluster to be used for data- and computation-intensive applications. The infrastructure supports research in three research areas: computational biology and bioinformatics; machine learning and data fusion; and infrastructure resilience and environmental sustainability. In each of these areas, there are multiple projects that benefit from the infrastructure.
This HPC cluster is the first such public infrastructure in South Jersey. Coupled with education and research programs focused on real-world problems, the HPC cluster aids classroom instruction in relevant courses in parallel processing and advanced computer architecture. HPC computation is incorporated into the curriculum of many general courses including the courses in Biomedical engineering, Computer Science, Chemistry and Biochemistry, Mathematics, Biological Sciences, Bioinformatics, and Electrical and Computer Engineering program.
The HPC facilitates expanded educational opportunities at the undergraduate level in all Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) areas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Previously a pre-dominantly undergraduate teaching institution, Rowan University has recently been re-designated as a “comprehensive research university” by the State of New Jersey, thereby dramatically expanding its mission to include cutting-edge research for scientific discovery and economic development. The new designation puts a big share of the responsibility on the Henry M. Rowan College of Engineering (HMRCOE) and the College of Science & Mathematics (CSM) in actively transforming Rowan to a true research university. Prior to this award, there were several emerging pockets of research excellence in the two colleges, primarily in the core areas of computational biology and bioinformatics, machine learning and artificial intelligence, infrastructure resilience and environmental sustainability, each being separately funded by National Science Foundation (NSF) or other federal agencies. A common thread among these areas is their involvement in data-intensive modeling, analysis and computation, and hence their need for the appropriate computational, memory and storage infrastructure that can accommodate such research. Yet, modest computational resources had thus far limited the true potential of our faculty and students in conducting larger scale and more transformative research in these areas.

This NSF grant assisted and sustained Rowan University’s transition into a comprehensive research university, making it the newest, and the only public research university in the State of New Jersey after Rutgers. The acquired High Performance Cluster (HPC) infrastructure enabled computational research in emerging and cutting-edge issues that were previously not possible at Rowan. Examples of new research projects that were enabled by this Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) acquisition include: (1) MRI brain imaging; (2) Molecular dynamics simulations of disordered proteins; (3) Genome-wide investigation of genetic variants; (4) Machine learning and artificial intelligence; (5) Intelligent transportation systems, including connected vehicles; (6) Environmental sustainability under the complex factors of climate change, variability and human impacts. The HPC cluster also facilitated expanded educational opportunities at the undergraduate level in all Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) areas. In addition, the new facility supported and enhanced graduate level education in all engineering and scientific areas, particularly data and computationally intensive research areas and applications. Less than two years after deployment, the cluster is hosting 25 software packages and serving 75 users from the diverse population of researchers at Rowan. Rowan’s first HPC website keeps information about the HPC specs, the list of software installed on it and provides user training and usage information: https://irt.rowan.edu/display/IRT/RUCC

Rowan’s HPC is currently being used by researchers across the university as well as at the Rowan College at Gloucester County (a community college that is affiliated with but independent of Rowan University). The equipment is also available to the South Jersey research, education and training communities. The research projects were part of undergraduate clinic projects, MS and expected PhD projects. Many of the projects are part of national or international collaborations, providing research and training experience for our students in the diverse areas listed above.

The HPC stimulated and enhanced the participation of women and underrepresented minorities in science and engineering through our dissemination, outreach efforts and subsequent K-12 STEM funding that leveraged upon this infrastructure. High-school students and K-12 teachers who participated in Rowan’s STEM summer camps visited the Rowan Data Center where the cluster is hosted. Equally importantly, the HPC system played a crucial role in recruiting new research active faculty, students and post-doctoral fellows, and is helping us transform Rowan into a model regional research university – not just in name, but in spirit, productivity and research output.
